user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 start_time, uint32 interval_time)
{
    OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t *local;
    struct itimerspec                   timeout;
    int32                               return_code;
    int                                 status;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *     timebase;

    local       = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_timebase_table, *token);
    timebase    = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, *token);
    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    /* There is only something to do here if we are generating a simulated tick */
    if (local->assigned_signal != 0)
    {
        /*
        ** Convert from Microseconds to timespec structures
        */
        memset(&timeout, 0, sizeof(timeout));
        OS_UsecToTimespec(start_time, &timeout.it_value);
        OS_UsecToTimespec(interval_time, &timeout.it_interval);

        /*
        ** Program the real timer
        */
        status = timer_settime(local->host_timerid, 0, /* Flags field can be zero */
                               &timeout,               /* struct itimerspec */
                               NULL);                  /* Oldvalue */

        if (status < 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error in timer_settime: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            return_code = OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL;
        }
        else if (interval_time > 0)
        {
            timebase->accuracy_usec = (uint32)((timeout.it_interval.tv_nsec + 999) / 1000);
        }
        else
        {
            timebase->accuracy_usec = (uint32)((timeout.it_value.tv_nsec + 999) / 1000);
        }
    }

    local->reset_flag = (return_code == OS_SUCCESS);
    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that modify any function parameter (token, start_time, interval_time) or the pointer parameter itself. Specific checks performed:

- token is only dereferenced via *token in OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...) to obtain object pointers (local and timebase). This reads the pointed value; it does not reassign the token pointer variable. Modifying the object pointed-to (local->... and timebase->...) is allowed by Rule 17.8.
- start_time and interval_time are passed by value (to OS_UsecToTimespec) and used in comparisons (interval_time > 0); there are no assignments to these parameters.
- There is no pointer arithmetic or reassignment involving token, nor any assignment to start_time or interval_time anywhere in the function.
- Calls such as OS_UsecToTimespec(...), timer_settime(...), and strerror(errno) do not modify the parameter variables in this function.

The only potential area to inspect further would be the definition of the macro/function OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET if it had surprising side effects; however, in this code it is invoked with *token (a value) and the expansion shown here does not reassign the token parameter. Therefore no fragments need investigating for Rule 17.8.
